ratings.long_description: Considers evidence from several sources. - Is able to avoid purely egocentric perspectives. - Recognized the limitations of the evidence and explains why it is limited.

- Considers some evidence. - Moves away from egocentric perspectives toward a focus on evidence from class and outside materials. - Claims that evidence might be limited or one-sided, but does not explain why.
Writes in Generalities. - Uses primarily personal experience. - Accepts information "as is." Does not indicate how evidence may be limited or one-sided.

Presents analysis of the information rather than accepting "as is." - Recognizes and avoids logical flaws. - Draws explicit connections between information from different sources. - Explores the contradictions or inadequacies in the evidence.

- Provides a cursory and superficial analysis of the evidence. - States that there are problems with the evidence, but only addresses with generalities. - Loosely ties information together from different sources. - Points out general contradictions or inadequacies in the information without explaining the specifics.

- Merely repeats information as truth of denies evidence without adequate justification. - Does not demonstrate an understanding of the flaws in the evidence. - Does not make connections among different sources. - Defends views based on self-interest or preconceptions.

- Constructs cogent arguments rooted in information presented rather than speculation and unsupported opinion, avoids overstated or understated conclusions. - Selects the strongest and most relevant information. - Identifies holes in the evidence and suggests additional information or types of information that might aid in analysis.
- Conclusions present a mix of unsupported opinion. - Selects some information to support conclusions, but may also use irrelevant information. - Identified holes in the information.

- Conclusions drawn heavily or completely on unsupported opinion. Draws unwarranted conclusions. - Does not use information to support conclusion(s). - Suggests no need for further explanation of the issue.

- Recognizes that the problem is complex with no clear answer, qualifies responses and acknowledges the need for additional information in making an absolute determination. - Proposes other specific options and weighs them in the decision. - Considers all stakeholders or affected parties in suggesting a course of action.

- Recognizes that the problem is complex with no clear answer. - Mentions the possibility of alternative options, without providing any details. - Suggests other stakeholders might be affected but doesn't specify who or why.
- Treats problem as simple one requiring an uncomplicated response. - Fails to identify or hastily dismisses alternative opinions. - Does not consider the impact on various stakeholders.

description:
#Concept1, #Application1

Students will write a paper that analyzes either:

  1. A specific aspect of climate change and its impacts and effects on society, or
  2. A specific aspect of the global food system. 

It will examine this as a social-ecological system with cross-scale interactions and incorporate the knowledge that we are acquiring in class in your analysis.  The report may cover it from the perspective of specific groups of people, take a local/regional/national/international perspective, focus on specific effects, focus on adaptation efforts, whatever.  There is a great deal of flexibility from this perspective. This is an analysis, so I will expect critical thought, cogent and coherent arguments, and personal insights only when building from evidence collected through research. 

Draw on what we have learned and discussed in this class – feedback loops, emergent outcomes, aspects of resilience, etc.  Your paper should have an introduction where you describe the specific system of interest, what the relevant issues/themes are, and who the key actors are.  You will then discuss and analyze the system.  You have a great deal of self-guided flexibility in this.  If you are unsure about format, content, the system that you are analyzing, etc, please contact me.

Your write-up should be evidence-based, not opinion.  Present your analysis of what you find across a variety of sources.  Where evidence is weak or non-existent, acknowledge that and fill in the gaps with logic and reasoned argumentation.  Identify the holes in your argument and suggest what future information could help bolster your case.  Acknowledge that the problem is complex and that there is room for multiple stakeholders’ perspectives. In short, use your critical thinking skills and clear written communication.

Students are expected to use at least 8 academic cites (Wikipedia can be used, but it doesn’t count for one of the citations). Should be approximately 5-7 pages double-spaced with 12 point Times New Roman font (including references). Use APA please. See the rubrics in the syllabus for guidance about grading criteria.  This will help you to understand the points from which I will be assessing the papers.
name: Systems Analysis Paper

discussion_topic.message:
Please provide an original example for both a one stock system and a two stock system.

Examples of One Stock Systems

  • A stock with two competing balancing loops: A thermostat
  • A stock with one reinforcing loop and one balancing loop: Population and Industrial Economy
  • A system with Delays: Business Inventory

Examples of Two Stock Systems

  • A Renewable Stock Constrained by a Nonrenewable Stock: An Oil Economy
  • Renewable Stock Constrained by a Renewable Stock: A Fishing Economy

discussion_topic.message:
Think about the places where you work, study, live, etc. Choose one of those settings. Now, give an example of general resilience at this place, and an example of specified resilience at this place. Then, consider what these resiliency factors are being resilient against. Why? Is it necessary?

So, your response should look something like this:

Briefly describe the setting you have chosen.

Example of general resilience. What makes it general?

Example of specific resilience. What makes it specific?

Why is it good or bad that these examples of resiliency exist the way they do?
discussion_topic.title: Discussion 5.2: General and Specified Resilience

discussion_topic.message:
#Concept3, #Application3

EXTRA CREDIT: 30 Points Max.

Derek and Laura Cabrera in Systems Thinking Made Simple developed the theory of "DSRP" as a means of systems thinking. This is a relatively new process/contribution to the field and is gaining a lot of traction and following. It plays on much of what the other books have covered. Here is DSRP in a super simplified sense:

D: Distinctions - What is and what is not.

S: Systems - Discernible parts that can be identified.

R: Relationships - Are those parts related and if so, how?

P: Perspectives - Considering the wants/needs/behaviors of a given part and relationship.

 

For your extra credit, think of a system you interact with daily (e.g. a regular task at your job, getting yourself or your kids ready for school, organizing an even you have coming up, etc.). You are going to be creating a map with 6 to 10 discernible parts that shows what needs to be considered in order to make your system happen. This will cover the D and the S part of the theory. Then, please be select with the relationships you choose to include by using a line ending in a arrow of influence (such as X----------> Y, so X affects Y), and try not to have too much crossings/overlap because then it gets messy and confusing.

Please include a side legend or accompanying write-up that accounts for the R and the P. The hope is that this actually helps you figure out something that has been or still is a challenge for you by applying a new perspective. You don't need to take on some huge worldy issue as your paper covered that, but see how systems actually play out in your life. It will help to make this class all the more meaningful to you. 

You can draw this out on paper and then scan/attach or use an online map maker, such as bubbl.us or draw.io (there are dozens of these things online so poke around). Please don't hesitate to ask a question, but before taking this on, please be sure that all other assignments are complete as missing scores hurt you more than adding a bunch of points at the end. 

Scoring: 10 points for how clear D and S are. 10 points for how clear R and P are. 10 points for how clear and organized the map itself is.
discussion_topic.title: Discussion 7.6: DSRP EXTRA CREDIT
